prompts.summary: Asked AI to conceive an active-learning browser game for teaching SQL injection concepts. Constraints: client-side only, zero dependencies, ideally involving students writing SQL-like input. AI designed 'SQL Injection Lab' — a 5-level cybersecurity training game with a lightweight simulated SQL engine, visible in-memory database, real-time query builder with injection highlighting, and a defence level where students parameterise queries.
prompts.outcome: AI produced a detailed implementation prompt covering: 5 levels (Authentication Bypass, UNION extraction, Boolean Blind, Destructive Stacked Queries, Defence Lab), a simulated SQL engine specification (SELECT/INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE/DROP, WHERE with AND/OR, UNION, SUBSTRING, comment stripping, stacked queries), visual design (dark terminal aesthetic, split panels for app/query/database/results), scoring, and file structure.

prompts.summary: Fed full implementation prompt to AI — included a complete SQL parser/evaluator spec (SimDB class with SELECT/INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE/DROP/UNION/SUBSTRING/stacked queries/comment stripping) plus 5-level game engine with sub-challenges, scoring, and visual design.
prompts.outcome: FAILED — LLM processing timed out. The combined complexity of writing a tolerant SQL parser AND a 5-level game engine in a single prompt exceeded the model's effective generation capacity.

prompts.summary: Revised approach: eliminated the SQL parser entirely. Replaced with pattern-matching evaluation — each level has a fixed query template, student input is string-concatenated for visual display, but attack detection uses regex/pattern matching against known injection signatures rather than actual SQL execution. Database panel uses static HTML tables manipulated via DOM. Reduces from 4 files to 3 (no sql-engine.js). Preserves the core pedagogical value (students see their input become part of SQL) while being implementable in a single prompt.
prompts.outcome: Produced a simplified implementation prompt. Key simplifications: (1) no SQL parser — pattern matching per level, (2) database display is DOM-based not query-driven, (3) reduced from 5 to 5 levels but with simpler mechanics for blind injection (guided stepper instead of freeform), (4) 3 files instead of 4.

prompts.summary: Fed the simplified implementation prompt (pattern-matching approach). AI generated all 3 files: index.html (76 lines — 3-column CSS Grid layout with top bar, app/query/database/results panels, overlay), style.css (413 lines — dark terminal theme with CSS variables, neon borders, SQL syntax colouring, password cracker animations, defence lab editor, damage report, responsive breakpoints), game.js (~530 lines — state machine, 5 complete levels with data/templates/detection/objectives/hints/explanations, overlay system for menu/briefings/completion, real-time query builder with injection highlighting, scoring engine, DOM-based database rendering with animations for table drops/row deletes/updates, defence lab with parameterised query validation and attack simulation).
prompts.outcome: SUCCESS — all 3 files generated in a single prompt execution. The simplified pattern-matching approach fit within the model's generation capacity. Total: ~1020 lines across 3 files.

prompt_strategy: Collaborative design → failed implementation (too complex) → design revision (pattern-matching instead of SQL parser) → simplified implementation (SUCCESS). Key learning: a full SQL parser + 5-level game exceeds single-prompt capacity; replacing the parser with pattern-matching made it feasible.
observations: Prompt 2 failed due to excessive complexity. The SQL parser spec alone was substantial — asking for SELECT/INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE/DROP with WHERE clause boolean logic, UNION, SUBSTRING, comment stripping, stacked queries, and error tolerance. Combined with 5 game levels each with sub-challenges and visual design, the total output requirement exceeded the model's generation window. Revised to use pattern-matching instead. Prompt 4 succeeded — the simplified approach generated all 3 files cleanly.

Level 1: Bonus objective 'Make the query return ALL user records' requires tautology injection (e.g. ' OR '1'='1' --). Researcher needed clarification — may indicate the in-game hints are insufficient for guiding students toward tautology vs comment-bypass distinction.

challenges.description: Implementation prompt 2 timed out — combined SQL parser + 5-level game engine was too much for a single generation. Resolved by eliminating the parser in favour of pattern-matching.

duration_estimate_note: Session wall-clock time approx 53 mins. WakaTime active editor time: 0 secs.
